prompt: Gen report: 54M, aspergilloma w/ productive cough with blood. Bronch done. Asp secretions. Inj Amphotericin into RLL. Cryo clot removal @ RLL Basal Carina and RML orifice. Thrombin for bleed. No comps.
completion:
NOTE_ID: note_012 SOURCE_FILE: note_012.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT
DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] INDICATION FOR OPERATION L.R. is a 54-year-old male who presents with aspergilloma and productive cough with blood.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed, and informed consent was obtained.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
Consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field
Aspergilloma
Productive cough with blood

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field
Aspergilloma
Productive cough with blood

PROCEDURE
Therapeutic aspiration of tracheobronchial tree (CPT 31645)
Therapeutic injection via endoscope channel (Amphotericin) (CPT 31573)
Destruction of tumor/relief of stenosis by cryotherapy (CPT 31641)
Bronchoscopy with application of Thrombin (CPT 31899)

ANESTHESIA Moderate sedation was administered.
The patient was monitored continuously by the attending physician while anesthesia was administered.
Medications: Etomidate 20 mg, Rocuronium 26 mg, Propofol 40 mcg/kg/min, Fentanyl 150 mcg/hr.

Duration: 50 minutes.
MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.1mm Cryoprobe.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS Minimal

COMPLICATIONS None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and procedure location.
Airway Inspection The bronchoscope was introduced through the tracheostomy tube. The tracheostomy tube was found to be in good position.
A Uniblocker was noted in place (deflated) at the Bronchus Intermedius.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal. Main carina sharp.
Right Lung: Proximal airways demonstrated normal anatomic branching to the segmental level. No evidence of mass or lesions.
Left Lung: Proximal airways demonstrated normal anatomic branching to the segmental level. No evidence of mass or lesions.
Secretions: Mild bloody secretions were noted, with right greater than left.

Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the airway segments from mucus, blood, and blood clots.
Segments Cleared: Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, Left Mainstem, Carina, RUL Carina (RC1), RML Carina (RC2), LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1), and Left Carina (LC2).

Therapeutic Injection (Amphotericin) Amphotericin (50 mg in 20 cc sterile water) was instilled into the Right Lower Lobe (RLL) as follows:
10 cc into the superior subsegment (RB6).
10 cc into the posterior basal subsegment (RB10).

Endobronchial Hemostasis Post-instillation, the patient had a mild ooze of fresh blood.
Hemostasis was achieved by applying Thrombin directly into the RLL through the bronchoscope (Total dose: 1000 mg).

Cryo-Extraction of Clot A formalized clot was identified causing obstruction at the RLL Basal Carina and RML orifice.
A 1.1 mm cryoprobe was applied to the clot with freeze times of 5–10 seconds.
Excellent clot removal was achieved, and the airway obstruction was relieved.

Conclusion The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
54-year-old male with aspergilloma and productive cough with blood.
Successful therapeutic aspiration and clearance of bloody secretions.
Successful instillation of Amphotericin into RLL.
Effective clot extraction via cryoprobe and hemostasis achieved with Thrombin.

Plan:
Continued care per primary team.
May consider repeat instillation of Amphotericin on next Monday and possible clot extraction.

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] INDICATION FOR OPERATION T.W. is a 57-year-old male who presents with pulmonary fungal ball and recurrent hemoptysis.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed, and informed consent was obtained.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
Consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field
Pulmonary fungal ball
Recurrent hemoptysis

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field
Pulmonary fungal ball
Recurrent hemoptysis

PROCEDURE
Therapeutic aspiration of tracheobronchial tree (CPT 31645)
Therapeutic injection via endoscope channel (Amphotericin B) (CPT 31573)
Destruction of tumor/relief of stenosis by cryotherapy (CPT 31641)
Bronchoscopy with application of Epinephrine (CPT 31899)

ANESTHESIA Moderate sedation was administered.
The patient was monitored continuously by the attending physician while anesthesia was administered.
Medications: Propofol 120 mcg/kg/min, Fentanyl 50 mcg boluses.

Duration: 50 minutes.
MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.1mm Cryoprobe.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS Minimal

COMPLICATIONS None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and procedure location.
Airway Inspection The bronchoscope was introduced through the tracheostomy tube. The tracheostomy tube was found to be in good position.
A Uniblocker was noted in place (deflated) at the Bronchus Intermedius.

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal. Main carina sharp.
Right Lung: Proximal airways demonstrated normal anatomic branching to the segmental level. No evidence of mass or lesions.
Left Lung: Proximal airways demonstrated normal anatomic branching to the segmental level. No evidence of mass or lesions.
Secretions: Mild bloody secretions were noted, with right greater than left.

Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the airway segments from mucus, blood, and blood clots.
Segments Cleared: Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, Left Mainstem, Carina, RUL Carina (RC1), RML Carina (RC2), LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1), and Left Carina (LC2).

Therapeutic Injection (Amphotericin B) Amphotericin B (50 mg in 20 cc sterile water) was instilled into the Right Lower Lobe (RLL) as follows:
10 cc into the superior subsegment (RB6).
10 cc into the posterior basal subsegment (RB10).

Endobronchial Hemostasis Post-instillation, the patient had a mild ooze of fresh blood.
Hemostasis was achieved by applying Epinephrine directly into the RLL through the bronchoscope (Total dose: 1000 mg).

Cryo-Extraction of Clot A formalized clot was identified causing obstruction at the RLL Basal Carina and RML orifice.
A 1.1 mm cryoprobe was applied to the clot with freeze times of 5–10 seconds.
Excellent clot removal was achieved, and the airway obstruction was relieved.

Conclusion The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
57-year-old male with pulmonary fungal ball and recurrent hemoptysis.
Successful therapeutic aspiration and clearance of bloody secretions.
Successful instillation of Amphotericin B into RLL.
Effective clot extraction via cryoprobe and hemostasis achieved with Epinephrine.

Plan:
Continued care per primary team.
May consider repeat instillation of Amphotericin B on pending clinical status and possible clot extraction.

Therapeutic aspiration of tracheobronchial tree (CPT 31645)
Therapeutic injection via endoscope channel (Amphotericin B) (CPT 31573)
Destruction of tumor/relief of stenosis by cryotherapy (CPT 31641)
Bronchoscopy with application of Thrombin (CPT 31899)

ANESTHESIA Moderate sedation was administered.
The patient was monitored continuously by the attending physician while anesthesia was administered.
Medications: Ketamine 50 mg, Propofol 100 mcg/kg/min.

Duration: 50 minutes.
MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.1mm Cryoprobe.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS Minimal

COMPLICATIONS None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and procedure location.
Airway Inspection The bronchoscope was introduced through the tracheostomy tube. The tracheostomy tube was found to be in good position.
A Uniblocker was noted in place (deflated) at the Left Mainstem Bronchus (LMSB).

Trachea: Distal 1/3 normal. Main carina sharp.
Right Lung: Proximal airways demonstrated normal anatomic branching to the segmental level. No evidence of mass or lesions.
Left Lung: Proximal airways demonstrated normal anatomic branching to the segmental level. No evidence of mass or lesions.
Secretions: Mild bloody secretions were noted, with left greater than right.

Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the airway segments from mucus, blood, and blood clots.
Segments Cleared: Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, Left Mainstem, Carina, RUL Carina (RC1), RML Carina (RC2), LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1), and Left Carina (LC2).

Excellent clot removal was achieved, and the airway obstruction was relieved.

There were no immediate complications.
